awd_titl_txt: The Economics of Rush-Hour Traffic Dynamics: Beyond the Bottleneck Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Traffic congestion is one of the banes of modern life.  Surprisingly, however, until recently very little systematic data had been collected on traffic congestion on urban streets (in contrast to freeways), which has hampered the development of well-informed policies for the alleviation of downtown traffic congestion. The recently collected data have generated an important finding:  the performance of the urban street system deteriorates sharply under heavily congested conditions -- more sharply than freeways.  This has two important policy implications.  First, it is important to implement policies that nip traffic jams in the bud.  Second, congestion pricing in downtown areas generates even larger social benefits than previously believed.  This research effort develops models of rush-hour traffic congestion on urban streets that account for this finding and applies them to analyze the effects of alternative congestion-relief policies. The research will support one Ph.D. student in applied mathematics, and encourage other such students to apply their technical skills to the study of downtown traffic congestion. 

The bottleneck model has been the workhorse model for the study of rush-hour traffic dynamics for a quarter of a century. While it has generated many insights, it has a serious flaw -- it assumes that traffic flow remains constant under heavily congested conditions.  Recent empirical study of the MFD -- macroscopic fundamental diagram -- in downtown areas has shown, to the contrary, that flow falls sharply under heavily congested conditions.  Previous work has developed a model of rush-hour traffic dynamics that accommodates the empirical MFD -- the isotropic model of downtown traffic congestion.  Unfortunately the model has proven analytically and numerically intractable.  The project aims to develop tractable algorithms to solve the model and also make progress in its analytical solution.   These tools will lead to more accurate analysis of policies aimed at alleviating downtown traffic congestion, including not only congestion pricing but also parking and congestion management policies.

Introduction

Traffic congestion is one of the banes of modern life. Yet it is part of the price that we, both individually and collectively, accept for the abundant benefits of urban life. Cities stimulate creativity, which enriches our culture and our leisure time, and inventiveness, which fuels our economic growth.

Urban transportation economists aim to manage traffic congestion efficiently. A first step is to understand the technology of traffic congestion, which is primarily the domain of transportation scientists and engineers. A second step is to identify inefficiencies in transportation infrastructure and its use, and to correct them, through improvements in capacity choice, traffic management, and pricing.

The project research focused on one aspect of traffic congestion -- rush-hour traffic dynamics. When a commuter decides when to depart for work in the morning, she can choose to depart early, in which case she encounters little traffic congestion but arrives at work earlier than she would like, or she can choose to depart so as to arrive on time but at the cost of encountering peak rush-hour traffic.

 

Intellectual Merit

This research contributes to a body of literature that aims to solve for the time pattern of departures over the rush hour, and hence a time pattern of congestion, such that no commuter can be better off by changing her departure time (the trip-timing equilibrium condition). This problem was first addressed almost fifty years ago by William Vickrey, a Nobel Prize winning economist, under the simplifying assumption that traffic congestion takes the form of a queue behind a bottleneck that allows cars through at a fixed rate. This "bottleneck model" of rush-hour congestion dynamics has been very widely applied in analyzing alternative policies to manage rush-hour traffic congestion.

Transportation scientists and economists have long recognized that this treatment of congestion, though physically sound, is oversimplified since it does not allow for traffic jams, and for many years have been searching for an alternative treatment of traffic congestion that at the same time is realistic and consistent with the laws of physics, generates simple mathematics, and admits traffic jams. The preferred alternative model has been "the bathtub model", which is built on the appealingly simple assumption that cars travel more slowly in denser traffic. Surprisingly, this simple treatment of traffic congestion leads to mathematics that is so advanced that, prior to this research, no one had succeeded in solving for the equilibrium pattern of departures even on a computer. To simplify the mathematics, researchers made "approximating assumptions" that are inconsistent with the physics of traffic flow. This would be acceptable in practice if the approximating assumptions lead to accurate solutions, but this has not been established.

This project's research "took the bull by the horns", developing an algorithm to solve for trip-timing equilibrium in the bathtub model, without approximating assumptions. Unfortunately, even in the simplest scenario in which commuters are identical and space is uniform, the equilibrium time patterns of departures, which is plotted below (with time on the x-axis and the departure rate on the y-axis), is complex.

There are three conclusions from the research:

1. The bathtub model does indeed generate complex mathematics. Thus, researchers should continue their quest for "an alternative treatment of traffic congestion that is realistic and consistent with the laws of physics, generates simple mathematics, and admits traffic jams."

2. Even though the bathtub model generates complex mathematics, equilibrium in the model can be solved on the computer "exactly".

3. For practical application, the most promising way forward, while inelegant, is to work with models that make approximating assumptions. With exact solution of the bathtub model on the computer now possible through this research, it will be possible to determine which approximating assumptions lead to more accurate approximate solution.

 

Broader Impacts

Most of the transportation science literature on street traffic congestion employs models that describe the street network in detail but provide only a crude treatment of traffic congestion, assuming that traffic speed is negatively related to traffic flow. In doing so, they ignore "traffic jam" situations, in which speed and flow are positively related. The project research focused on these traffic jam situations employing an aggregative description of the street network. Since traffic jams are pervasive during the downtown rush hour peak, the project research contributed to the emerging theory of downtown traffic congestion.

The project employed a Ph.D. student in applied mathematics, who wrote up his project research in two Ph.D. thesis chapters. One has already been published in a leading transportation journal. The experience he gained in applying computational mathematics and in writing up research results for publication, and the knowledge he acquired of traffic flow theory and the economics of traffic congestion, should help launch him a successful research career.
